resource descriptions.descriptionText: PubMed is a searchable database of medical literature and lists journal articles that discuss Non-A-E hepatitis. Click on the link to view a sample search on this topic.
The National Digestive Diseases Information Clearinghouse (NIDDK) offers information on this condition. Click on the link to view information on this topic.

overviewQuestion.answerText: Non-A-E hepatitis, sometimes referred to as hepatitis X, is a disease of the liver that is diagnosed when there is swelling of the liver (hepatitis) but examination and testing does not identify a cause.  Symptoms of non-A-E hepatitis may include feeling tired or unwell (malaise), nausea, vomiting, pain in the abdomen, and fever.  Non-A-E hepatitis usually goes away on its own, but it can become a chronic condition in a small proportion (12%) of affected individuals.  The cause of non-A-E hepatitis is currently unknown.[5397]

gardCases.abbreviatedInquiry: I am trying to find information about transmission of hepatitis X.  Is it found in Europe or just the USA?

caseQuestions.answerText: Non-A-E hepatitis, sometimes referred to as hepatitis X, is a disease of the liver that is diagnosed when there is swelling of the liver (hepatitis) but examination and testing does not identify a cause.  Symptoms of non-A-E hepatitis may include feeling tired or unwell (malaise), nausea, vomiting, pain in the abdomen, and fever.  Non-A-E hepatitis usually goes away on its own, but it can become a chronic condition in a small proportion (12%) of affected individuals.  The cause of non-A-E hepatitis is currently unknown.[5397]

references.authors: Delic D, Mitrovic N, Spurnic AR, Svirtlih NS, Babic JS
references.articleTitle: Epidemiological characteristics and clinical manifestations of acute non-A-E hepatitis

caseQuestions.questionText: How does an individual become affected by non-A-E hepatitis?
caseQuestions.answerText: The cause of non-A-E hepatitis has not yet been discovered.  Some researchers suggest that there are likely several unidentified infectious agents, such as unknown viruses, that may cause this disease.  Individuals affected by this condition have not consistently been found to have exposures to known risk factors for hepatitis (such as having dental work or medical procedures, working in health care, or traveling to areas where hepatitis is common).[5397][5398][5399]

references.articleTitle: Acute non-A-E hepatitis in the United States and the role of hepatitis G virus infection. Sentinel Counties Viral Hepatitis Study Team

caseQuestions.questionText: In what countries has non-A-E hepatitis been found?
caseQuestions.answerText: Non-A-E hepatitis has been identified in individuals worldwide.[5398]

references.authors: Chu CM, Lin DY, Yeh CT, Sheen IS, Liaw YF
references.articleTitle: Epidemiological characteristics, risk factors, and clinical manifestations of acute non-A-E hepatitis

news.title: NIH-Supported Research Survey to Examine Impact of COVID-19 on Rare Diseases Community
news.description: The NIH-funded Rare Diseases Clinical Research Network (RDCRN) has launched an online research survey to find out how the COVID-19 pandemic is impacting individuals with rare diseases, their families and their caregivers. Your participation can help the rare disease research community shed light on the needs of people with rare diseases during this and other potential health crises, in addition to informing future research efforts. The survey must be completed by December 15, 2020.
